Posts.Content: It gets better!  Unfortunately, sickness is harder to treat once it gets a grip but it will go.  Ask if they can change your meds from the start for the next round.  Emend is the really effective one.  Also, just because you are really sick on one round doesn't mean it will happen every time. I've been fasting on the day before, day of, and day after chemo - plenty of fluids but no more than 200 cals a day.  Can't say if this has helped, but I haven't had nausea on the rounds I've done it. Nicola x
Posts.Title: Does this sea-sickness feeling go away?

Posts.Content: The horrible truth of the matter is that the vast majority of people who endure adjuvant chemo either don't need it, or don't benefit from it.  We are living with the reality of lack of medical knowledge combined with some very toxic chemicals, many of which are the same ones that have been used for decades.  They have serious short term and long term risks.  But then so does cancer. Personally, I think it sucks.  My own benefit was estimated at 3-4 percent, but the oncologist guesstimated it up to 6-7 percent because of the HER2+ status.  They don't actually have statistically reliable figures for HER2+ with regards to chemo but you have to have it, otherwise you can't have Herceptin.  To me, that still mean that I"m more likely to be in the 93-94 women out of a hundred for whom chemo is of no benefit.  Good in some ways, but bad when you are suffering the side effects. If you are not HER2+, there is a test that can be done that examines your own case more accurately, with regards to the cancer markers.  It's called oncotype I think.  It's expensive, although some people seem to get it free (postcode lottery, again).   Whatever you decide, I think you have to set your mind to it and know that it was the right decision for you.  A rock and a hard place is a little bit what it feels like to me.
Posts.Title: Anyone had to choose whether or not to have Chemo?? Confused

Posts.Content: I am in the facebook group and think it is great - it means you can talk to 'real' people with names and faces but also know that your conversation can't be pawed over by every Tom, Dick or Harry on the internet.  It can feel a bit like sitting in an old people's home in the chemo ward, which as well as making me feel old before my time is a bit depressing.  It's good to be able to see a bunch of younger looking women and feel less odd one out.  I also think that the fact people are using their real identities may avoid some of the bitchiness / misunderstandings that can sometimes flair up on anonymous forums.
Posts.Title: Younger women Facebook group

Posts.Content: I haven't got my wig yet - appointment is on Monday.   The hospital eventually got around to calling me to sort it out with some half-baked excuse as to why it had taken so long (I just block their uselessness out now unless it is something really important).  I'm now 15 days post first FEC and already all shaved off as was coming off in clumps.  Not sure how I will feel about the wig - the website for the place I have to go looks quite provincial and old-fashioned.  I guess they have to suit everybody and that makes the whole thing a bit conservative / older.  Reminds me of the sort of 'boutiques' my grannie used to shop in. For a bit of inspiration- and something that's more 'me' - I've put together a couple of pinterest boards.  Take a look if you fancy. http://pinterest.com/yachtninky/stylish-scarves-and-headwear/ http://pinterest.com/yachtninky/bald-beauty/ All the best everyone, Nicola
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi YvonneN - thanks for the advice.  I'm going to take my mum - she's not the cutting edge of fashion but hopefully will help to support my choices.   I've treated myself to a couple of hats this weekend.  I'm finding that wearing a buff/morph underneath felt hats like trilbies / cloches really helps them stay on the head better, as well as giving better coverage.  Looks pretty stylish too and you can have fun with colour combos. My eyelashes have now started to come out too :(
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne - I've been doing the fasting thing too.  Just having water and very thin vegetable soup the day before, day of and day after.  Unfortunately it didn't work so well for me.  Maybe I should cut out the soup as well.  I vomited so much it put me off water for a few days - as that was pretty much all I was bringing up!
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: A friend of my OH came round and said "In my country we say there are two types of cancer, optimistic and pessimistic" (meaning curable and terminal).  Then added, "Which one have you got?" Another classic on This Morning the other day.  They were talking about a (small scale) study that showed being married led to much better outcomes for lung cancer patients.  One of the guests said, "It's probably because they've got children so they've got more reason to live".  Obviously, being childfree, my life isn't worth living then?! I do find a lot of friends are blatantly worried about themselves and a lot of what they say is transparent anxiety about their own risk factors.  The very fact your friend said "I feel invincible" suggests the opposite really.  People who feel invincible don't ponder over their own mortality.
Posts.Title: so annoyed with crass comments

Posts.Content: I haven't got my wig yet - appointment is on Monday.   The hospital eventually got around to calling me to sort it out with some half-baked excuse as to why it had taken so long (I just block their uselessness out now unless it is something really important).  I'm now 15 days post first FEC and already all shaved off as was coming off in clumps.  Not sure how I will feel about the wig - the website for the place I have to go looks quite provincial and old-fashioned.  I guess they have to suit everybody and that makes the whole thing a bit conservative / older.  Reminds me of the sort of 'boutiques' my grannie used to shop in. For a bit of inspiration- and something that's more 'me' - I've put together a couple of pinterest boards.  Take a look if you fancy. http://pinterest.com/yachtninky/stylish-scarves-and-headwear/ http://pinterest.com/yachtninky/bald-beauty/ All the best everyone, Nicola
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: Hi YvonneN - thanks for the advice.  I'm going to take my mum - she's not the cutting edge of fashion but hopefully will help to support my choices.   I've treated myself to a couple of hats this weekend.  I'm finding that wearing a buff/morph underneath felt hats like trilbies / cloches really helps them stay on the head better, as well as giving better coverage.  Looks pretty stylish too and you can have fun with colour combos. My eyelashes have now started to come out too :(
Posts.Title: How did you react to getting your wigs?

Posts.Content: I had my first FEC chemo yesterday.  Finished around 5pm and didn't have first vomit until 10pm - although was feeling pretty funky from about 8pm.  All I would say is do you have a closer hospital, or medical backup, incase of emergency? If you do get an infection you may need to get seen ASAP.
Posts.Title: Chemo starting next Tuesday

Posts.Content: With the chemo, I don't think they can guarantee on every cancer, because they're not all the same.  Some of them are crafty buggers and don't respond so well to the drugs, so throwing the radiotherapy is just an extra line of attack.
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Oral hygiene is really important as your mouth gets sore and sensitive.  Baby toothbrush is a good idea to protect gums.  Also toothpaste with aloe vera (health food shops).  Worth having some music / movies you like to fill the time and take your mind off things the first few days - I found I couldn't read much due to chemo brain.  Hand cream - nice to treat yourself and keep the skin in good condition.  Straws - good for drinking with a sore mouth.  Batch freeze some meals or have someone else to do meal / food prep for you for first few days.
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: YvonneN - what time of day do you get your chemo?  Mine isn't until the afternoon.  I think going to bed full of chemo doesn't help either.  I think I might try to doze sitting up for a bit!
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Mr_T don't know if your wife has discovered oat 'milk' but I really like it for smoothies and cereal.  You can get from Tesco / H&B
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: Mr_T I'm not eating dairy and avoiding sugar.  I have succumbed to a couple of icecreams since diagnosis but some people (including myself) suspect dairy boosts oestrogen levels which is not good for ER+ breast cancer.  It's not a universally agreed theory though.  Generally I'm trying to eat mainly fruit and veg and some oily fish, pulses, seeds and nuts. Sugar also feeds yeast - and systemic candida (thrush) can be a real problem with chemotherapy. It can make you really ill as well as leaving oral and gastric lesions which make eating unpleasant. It's a toss up though because sometimes something sugary is all you really fancy (I see a lot of people suggesting ice pops and other sugary things while on chemo).  Personally, I have manuka honey to add sweetness, or even on its own.  It's a natural healer and will help strengthen the immune system rather than weaken it (as sugar can do).   You can get a free DVD that has advice on diet and other stuff from a place called The Haven.  If you live near a centre they also offer free complementary therapies and counselling.
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: one more for the survival kit - dark nail poiish.  Helps to protect nail and minimise breakages / nail loss.
Posts.Title: Suggestions for a chemo survival tool kit please!

Posts.Content: I believe the 100 percent Aloe Vera one they sell in Holland and Barrett is okay.
Posts.Title: Cream for radiotherapy?

Posts.Content: Hi, we have a September chemo-buddies thread on a different forum.  The more the merrier.  It's a bit of a rubbish forum to navigate unfortunately. http://www.breastcancercare.org.uk/comment/2051490#comment-2051490
Posts.Title: Starting chemo 26th

Posts.Content: I wouldn't be worried about the other drugs.  They know all the ingredients in the tablets you have reacted to and will be able to give you something that won't have the same response.  Most allergic reactions aren't life threatening anyway, at least not to start with, just really unpleasant - unfortunately the way they get reported in the media you'd think anyone with an allergy would drop dead without an instant epipen the second they come in contact with what they are allergic to.  I have loads of allergies from hayfever to pet hair but have been okay with most medicines apart from penicillin (I have a mould allergy).  Generally an antihistamine can take the edge off and then you just avoid whatever you are allergic to as much as possible.  The good news is they can find something else for you to take.
Posts.Title: itchy skin

Posts.Content: I think you should speak to your BCN / GP because it could potentially be an allergic reaction - sounds very similar to how I was to penicillin, although a rash appeared then as well.  I started tamoxifen last Wednesday and no itchy skin.  Just a bit of stomach ache and occasional bloating.  Hope it gets better for you, my brand is Wockhardt by the way.
Posts.Title: itchy skin

Posts.Content: Thanks for that.  I too have given up soya.  In the two years prior to diagnosis I had significantly increased my intake as I considered it a healthy protein source.  I was having various types, tofu, soya milk, edame beans generally every day.  I am also HER2+. I have been told that daily moderate exercise is good too, although excessive exercise has apparently been shown to increase recurrence risk.
Posts.Title: Soya or not? HER2+ Report after meeting dietician

Posts.Content: Hello!  Yes I'm doing the fasting thing.  It was recommended to me by someone who worked on a documentary that featured it.  The human trials I'm aware of have been for day before, day of and day after.  You are allowed 200 calories on those days (avoiding protein).  I'm 3 FEC cycles in now.  The first cycle I was less strict with the fast (mainly due to pressure from OH) and was very nauseous and sick for the first 24 hours.  The next 2 cycles I was strict with it and had no sickness / nausea.  I've still had usual hairloss, tiredness and this cycle had a chest infection (although that was a germ I would likely have picked up anyway) and the antibiotics for that gave me some unpleasant side effects.   I do feel I'm generally coping very well with the chemo.  Whether the fasting has helped I can't really say - it's not a clinical trial.  I feel as though it has helped, but this could well be placebo / coincidence.  My oncologist said she didn't recommend it (fair enough, not been proven yet).  If you are underweight it's probably not a good idea.
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: My feeling is the absolutely essential day for preventing the sickness is chemo day itself.  On that day my only calories are a banana in the morning, emergen-c vitamin sachet (H&B) and then I  have a Purdeys (a fruit based fizzy vitamin drink again from H&B) whilst my chemo is going in (mine is done in the afternoon).  The day before and day after I eat small (and I mean small) bowls of homemade vegetable soup and a banana.  I also try to drink plenty of water and fruit/herb tea. Good luck with it.  Chemo is not pleasant but so far has not been as bad as I feared. Nicola x
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: Good point kelzy.  However, although you do need some food with steroids to protect the gut, you don't need to have a full meal.  You can just have a piece of fruit (banana) or something small.  That said, steroids can make some people feel very hungry, so that might make calorie restriction more of a challenge.  I haven't done fasting with docetaxal yet and there are more steroids to take with those compared to FEC, so will see how it goes.
Posts.Title: Fasting Before & After Chemo

Posts.Content: It's not going to stop the chemo working at all.  My own skeptical take is reiki is a load of baloney but it's not harmful - (other than if people start doing it INSTEAD of conventional treatment) - and if it makes you feel relaxed then that's a good thing.  Stress reduction will help lessen side effects, but not desired effects. I had a friend offer to do some reiki down the phone for me.  I wondered if it somehow mysteriously worked over email too :)
Posts.Title: Complementary therapy - Reiki

Posts.Content: I think some women (and men too) get jealous of the attention other people get from being ill.  Hard to believe but my own mother does this.  When my gran (her mother-in-law) was ill she dismissed it, even though she'd broken her collar bone, was in her 90s and had had more than one stroke my mum would insist she was putting things on to get sympathy.  Now I've got breast cancer and she goes on about any medication she's ever had herself, any health problem she's ever had herself.  Even said at one point I was making a fuss (I really am not) because lots of women have breast cancer (as if that makes it nothing to worry about!).  My husband doesn't even want to see her at the moment he is that angry about it.
Posts.Title: Accused of making it up

Posts.Content: I'm a humanist.  This means I don't believe in a divine being or creator.  This usually doesn't make much difference but since I've been diagnosed it's becoming an issue.  This is because people who are religious (even those who know I don't believe) insist on making comments that are really winding me up.   I've had "God only gives us what we can cope with" and "God does things for a reason".  Also many people saying they are praying for me.  Thanks, I'd rather have something useful like a meal cooked for me or an offer to drive me to the hospital.   The worst is the hospital.  Every time I go it seems there is a member of staff who mentions God or Jesus.   I know that they mean well, but it isn't helpful.  Quite the opposite.  It makes me feel like the situation must be desperate if even people who work with all the weight of science to call on think they should suggest praying for me.  Makes me think of witch doctors and faith healers and all sorts of voodoo nonsense.  My OH says I shouldn't get wound up or say anything because they are doing it to be nice. Well, religious people, it's not nice.  Please don't assume others share your faith or want to hear about it when they are going through a difficult time.
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Well your answers have put a smile on my face. Humour is probably the best way to deal with it.  I think it's worse when I'm feeling vulnerable and upset because that's often when I fail to see a funny side to things and hurt and anger kick in. I don't think it is illegal for the hospital staff to make religious comments but they should probably be trained to keep their unverified views to themselves.  There are religious outlets at the hospital already for those who want them (prayer room etc).   It's possible some religiously-minded friends and family even thought my diagnosis might make me find some faith.  As if getting a nasty and potentially terminal illness is something that would suddenly make me think there is an all-powerful being deciding these things, who might turn it round if I whisper enough of the right words. The mind boggles :)
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for that Joycee.  Just what I was looking for!
Posts.Title: How to stop / deal with religious comments

Posts.Content: Cording can return any time after surgery I believe.  I know that if I don't do the arm exercises for a couple of days, mine starts to come back, and I only had 4 nodes removed.
Posts.Title: Pains in arm where lymph nodes removed in January - starting to panic...

Posts.Content: The reason I checked my breasts and found a lump was because I found out someone I knew had breast cancer.  Lots of people checked their breasts after finding out I had breast cancer.  I think people like Kylie have also done a lot in terms of being open about their condition. I don't think this campaign actually works.  If someone comes back and says they found a breast lump after seeing the picture of Mel B and checking their breasts then it will be worth it.  But I think there are a lot more effective campaigns.  People need to realise it could happen to them.  This doesn't do that at all.  The message should be love your body, but love your life more.
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Hi Sheila, Sorry to hear of your diagnosis.  I'm currently having chemotherapy.  I was concerned about how it would impact my asthma, but if anything my breathing has improved due to the steroids given to boost your system with the drugs.  I can't comment on ME or fibromyalgia, but rest assured the team treating you will do everything to manage all of your health conditions through treatment.  It is worth making a note of questions to ask the oncologist who will see you prior to each chemo treatment.  Raise your worries about any specific health problems or side effects with them at these appointments and make sure you know the emergency numbers.  There are few silver linings with cancer, but I've found that one of them is that you get 24/7 doctor on-call to speak to if you have any worrying symptoms (with NHS treatment at least).  You also get free prescriptions for five years, which means if you do have any other health conditions that require medication you normally pay prescription fee for, you can actually save a bit of money.   The first few weeks following diagnosis can be the hardest, because there are so many changes to adjust to - emotional, financial, practical.  But there is a lot of support out there, possibly more so than other diseases.  I've had free massages and counselling, and I'm going to a free makeover session with goodie bag (Look Good, Feel Better), also a younger women's forum in Brighton that involves a free night in a hotel and meal - never got anything like that for my lifelong asthma condition. Nicola x
Posts.Title: New to the Group worrying about the whole Breast Cancer situation...

Posts.Content: Reckon next time she could promote oral cancer 'awareness' by sticking her foot in her mouth.  She clearly has a talent in that direction.
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: Excellent, a bitching thread!  Well done SR, was getting a bit sick of all the sistahood and hugs.  Didn't see what she's done but I'll join you in ranting about selfish attention-seeking sleb campaigners.  Bleurghh...
Posts.Title: Mel B´s "campaign"

Posts.Content: I had a lump that didn't show on mammogram or ultrasound - but could be felt.  Also very slight dimpling.  If the lump can be felt they should be able to biopsy it even if it doesn't show up on the screening.  THat's the only way to tell if it is cancer or not.
Posts.Title: Lump, dimpling to the skin but clear ultrasound-still worried

Posts.Content: I had the MRI contrast thing to check whether there were any extra nasties.  It's a lot more sensitive (and expensive!) than a mammogram.  You have to go in the MRI machine face down, takes a good 20 minutes to half an hour.  You get an injection ('contrast') midway through that shows up the cancers on the scan better.  They're sensitive but can give false positives (mine did).  Still, I'd personally have the stress of a false positive that then gets countered by a clear biopsy than have them miss something.
Posts.Title: Lump, dimpling to the skin but clear ultrasound-still worried

Posts.Content: Yes the rooms are a bit grim and the average age does tend to be a bit older - I guess this is to be expected as people are more likely to get cancer as they age.  I felt young in there and I'm 40.  Good luck with chemo 1.  Apart from feeling a bit cold and the initial needle going into your arm there's not much to it really.  I'd advise not eating beforehand or only having something light like a banana and drink plenty of water / fluids.  Also I found that lying down later if/when feeling giddy tends to bring on the sickness so avoid that if you can. And take the anti-sickness they give you even if you don't feel sick.  Some music to listen to is also a good idea, Good luck. x
Posts.Title: chemo day 2moro

Posts.Content: Oh what a lot to deal with.  It's horrible when you think you've just about coped with the first news and then it changes.  I can so identify with this.  I had to have an MRI scan as my tumour hadn't shown on the mammogram and I got the call at work that they thought they had found two more 'areas'.  Had to go home in floods of tears and that was the end of my attempt to keep working.  I know it is very hard to stay off the google but remember you are an individual not a probability.  You could find out that you have a 90 percent chance of survival and end up in the unlucky10 percent or have only a 3 percent chance of survival and be in that 'lucky' 3 percent. My oncologist gave me the survival sheets for my cancer stage (unfortunately they don't cover HER2 so they just make an educated guess with that one) and I was surprised to see I have a 2 percent chance of dying from something altogether different in the next 10 years anyway, and always have!   I think this disease screws with your head more than anything and a lot of that is fed by other people's fear of it too.  We're dealing with a massive human fear here - not just the the fear of dying but the fear of dying slowly and in pain.  Somehow we have to navigate ourselves around that along with the pressure to be positive all the time.
Posts.Title: Different day, different diagnosis. Now it is HER2+

Posts.Content: Really sorry to hear that LM.  I've just started the chemo and herceptin road 'cos her2+ but didn't have the node clearance.  Doesn't it just make you feel special when they 'clear a space"!  Hardly the VIP area you want to be let in to, is it?  You might find you feel okay after the node clearance as you did with the MX.  Here's hoping those hairy bollocks get a good kicking.
Posts.Title: Got some bad news today

Posts.Content: Bloody brilliant.  I can't wait until I join the 'Finished Chemo Club'.   A virtual booze-free cheers from me.
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Ive just made the difficult choice of accepting chemo (HER2 positive so have to have chemo in order to have herceptin).  First session on 5th September. I still don't know if it is the right decision.  I worry about possible longterm side effects and ongoing illness caused by the treatment and mull over the fact that my cancer could well have already gone (clear nodes and margins).  Perhaps it is a similar doubt that drives others to be argumentative with those who have made a different decision.  It's because there is an insecurity in their own choice.  People often find security in the crowd and finding that someone has decided to do something differently undermines this.   The important thing to remember is we are all stuck between a rock and a hard place when it comes to living with BC.  And even if you've chosen the hard place and someone else has chosen the rock, you're both going through a difficult situation.  Whatever the outcome of our choice it's not our fault.  We're all just finding a way through between hope and fear.
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: Up to you but I'd much rather go for a drug that has had rigorous clinical trials than a so-called 'natural' alternative that hasn't.  If this other thing actually blocks oestrogen effectively I don't see how it can have no side effects, since oestrogen creates strong effects on the body that blocking it would alter. I've been on tamoxifen for 2 weeks now and can honestly say I've not had any terrible side effects.  Upset tum for a couple of days (but could have been something else I'd eaten) and very mild and occassional sense of being overheated that I usually get before my period anyway - and since my period still started on the day it was due (wasn't expecting that to happen) I feel fine.  So think the so-called side effects were just my usual PMT. Tamoxifen is a very effective drug for ER+ cancer and I'd be willing to give it a go at least.  If the effects are too awful you can always stop taking it but you won't know unless you try. By serious side effects I assume you mean the slightly elevated risk of womb cancer?  My thinking is to deal with the here and now cancer.  The increased risk of future uterine cancer is very slight, especially if you have no additional risk factors.  Unfortunately it is much slighter than the risk of breast cancer recurrence.
Posts.Title: I need to make a decision

Posts.Content: Glad to hear you are doing so well so far into your treatment.  I didn't know about the +8/9 number.  What is that?  They haven't given me a number, just told me the cancer was her2 receptive.
Posts.Title: Not sure if I still belong here or not?

Posts.Content: foxyferret I'm stage 1 also and have also never felt ill.  I think this is typical of many people diagnosed with breast cancer.  In fact, prior to being diagnosed I'd never felt healthier as I'd been doing loads of exercise and eating well.  I think like you I probably had the stereotypical notion that if you have cancer you must be a fairly unhealthy person with an unhealthy lifestyle.  It seems cancer actually has other ideas.  Who knows why we've got it, but the fact is we have.  The chances are the cancer has been removed by surgery.  However, the consequences of being in the less likely group (cancer can spread via the bloodstream, bypassing the lymph nodes) are so serious I personally think it's worth chucking everything at it.  Unlike you, I'm also HER2 positive so will be starting 6 months of chemo followed by 12 months of herceptin before I even get to radiotherapy stage.  So lots more side effects and feeling ill to get through.
Posts.Title: I need to make a decision

Posts.Content: It's to do with staging (size, lymph nodes etc).  If your indicators (e.g. clear margins lo/no node involvement) show an early stage, then a CT scan is not considered necessary.
Posts.Title: How do I know if its spread?

Posts.Content: Proper medicine all the way for me.  Alternatives have not proved themselves in sufficient clinical trials.  Mainly they seem to feed off the fear people have of side effects from proper medicine.  That fear is understandable, the treatment is not pleasant and in some cases the side effects can be long lasting, but I don't think I'd want to trust my life to quacks instead.   However, it is your choice.   You might want to google Kathy Acker whilst you're making it.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: The treatments offered by the NHS are not cheap.  On top of all the screening tests that involve very expensive equipment (e.g.MRI machine) and highly qualified staff, I've had surgery and will be having 6 rounds of chemo, radiotherapy, herceptin for 12 months (v. costly drug) with regular nuclear medicine scans to check heart function, also hormone therapy.  There is a massive backup team, path lab etc. looking over cases.  Also the basic running costs of the hospital, keeping it clean etc.  It's often the alternative providers, and even private providers, that try to cut costs but still charge through the nose for their end product.  For example, chemotherapy is often given at home by private insurance, a lot cheaper because this means VAT isn't charged on the drugs and a clinical, staffed environment doesn't need to be provided.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Here is a link to the Cancer Research UK response.  http://www.cancerresearchuk.org/cancer-info/news/archive/pressrelease/2012-10-30-cruk-response-to-breast-screening-review?utm_source=twitter_cr_uk&utm_medium=cruksocialmedia&utm_campaign=owntwitter_tweet   I wonder if there is a connection to age?  By the time you are in your 80s you have a really high chance of getting breast cancer, but chances are you will die from something else first.  However, any cancer in younger women has got a long time ahead to grow and develop.  Only screening over 50s has always seemed a little odd to me.  Yes, you are more likely to have cancer at that age, but it is also less likely to kill you.
Posts.Title: BBC Report

Posts.Content: I'm having the same treatment as you.  Only had my first FEC so far.  I too hope to go back to work after the chemo.  I'm self-employed so don't get any sick pay if I don't work - also my work is very full-on, long hours and often weekends too. It's also very reputation-based, so I really need to be fully functioning in order to go back because I can't just drift in and do a few quiet hours at a desk.  At the hospital I've been told a lot of people go back to work on Herceptin, but I do wonder what sort of work, because not all jobs are the same.
Posts.Title: FEC-T and Heceptin ??? What to expect?

Posts.Content: Most breast cancers contain parabens but using paraben-free cosmetics doesn't actually reduce risk from them because there are so many in the environment.  That's why there is no link between using paraben-free cosmetics and reduced breast cancer.  There are also many naturally occuring parabens such as in blueberries. I have changed to paraben-free stuff for most things but have to admit this is largely irrational.  What we do as an individual is a drop in the ocean compared to what we are doing as a society - it's the social (industrial) scale where the effects are largest.  Unfortunately, most public health campaigns don't highlight this.
Posts.Title: Parabens

Posts.Content: Hi Annie, So sorry to hear your results weren't what you were hoping for.  I really hope the tax does the trick against your primary and mets. I'm moving onto tax next week too, although I only have 3 and then a year of herceptin. Could they explain why some of the mets have shrunk?  Is it possible that there are a couple of different types of cancer cells and so some responded well to the first chemo, and the others may well respond well to the tax?  I'm not an oncologist so just guessing really.  The good thing is they still have some weapons up their sleeve to try.  You've already acheived a massive thing by getting through the first chemos - which did shrink some if not all of the cancer.    How are you feeling generally energy and healthwise at the moment?  Wishing you all the best for tax #1 and beyond.   Nicola x
Posts.Title: Not great scan results :(

Posts.Content: I have been told that once treatment starts it is a good idea not to delay more than two sessions as this can reduce effectiveness. For example, this link states that treatment gaps may be more harmful than a short delay in starting treatment. http://www.rcr.ac.uk/audittemplateCO.aspx?PageID=1653&AuditTemplateID=10
Posts.Title: What if I can't get to the hospital because of the snow for rads?

Posts.Content: All a bit old now but my mindless entertainment recommendations include...   There's something about Mary Meet the Fockers / Meet the parents Strictly dance fever If my chemo brain gets any worse I'll be struggling with Bagpuss.
Posts.Title: The Film Thread

Posts.Content: I had my lumpectomy in mid June.  There is still a trace of the dye around the nipple - although now looks grey rather than blue.  It's definitely faded considerably but not gone completely.
Posts.Title: Blue/green dye from Sentinel Node Biopsy

Posts.Content: I wouldn't assume that every one has fantastic BC nurses.  I haven't heard from mine since beginning of July and she's fairly chocolate teapot when I do speak to her.  I get far more accurate info from websites and helplines.  The difference in the level of treatment and care across the UK is so massive, you might as well live in a different country sometimes.
Posts.Title: Wishing everyone well and goodbye

Posts.Content: Don't leave Sascha.  I love reading your posts because you are totally honest and don't pretend there's a silver lining to everything and how everything can be made better with a little more optimism.  We're all going through this in our own unique way, and everyone, and their response, is as valuable as the next person.  It's not a popularity competition FFS.
Posts.Title: Wishing everyone well and goodbye

Posts.Content: I'm pretty sure that only products with peroxide will lighten the hair.  Although I do remember people putting lemon juice on and then going out in the sun when I was a teenager.  If you live somewhere sunny this might be an option, but I can't guarantee what it will come out like.
Posts.Title: Hair colour??

Posts.Content: I too recommend Farmaline for  Evonail.  Delivery was very quick and they emailed and sent a text with the actual hour the delivery would be made (and actually arrived in the hour the said). So no waiting around all day for drivers that fail to show.  I've decided to paint the nails a very dark red and use the evonail for the nail bed and around the nail where you would want to use polish - hopefully will work out a bit cheaper and I won't need another bottle of the Evonail which is expensive.  I'm also keeping the nails cut very short.
Posts.Title: The wonders of evonail - day 13 no nail damage

Posts.Content: I only had a lumpectomy but yes I did get this!  Wore off after a while.
Posts.Title: A bit of a weird one.....

Posts.Content: I too am tortured by the yeast infections (have had it in my mouth too now following chemo!).  Had the worst case (vaginal) after antibiotics following second op to remove haematoma.  I went to my GP who gave me a prescription for canesten.  You can just buy it at Boots but if you have your five year medical exemption certificate then the prescription will save you a few quid.
Posts.Title: Embarassing, but I need relief!

Posts.Content: congenial - I think it depends how severe it is.  Not to scare anyone, but you can be hospitalised for thrush whilst on chemo if it is very severe.  In fact, although bacterial infections are the most common whilst on chemo, it's the fungal infections that are most often fatal.  Have a look at this.  http://www.modernmedicine.com/modernmedicine/article/articleDetail.jsp?id=126075 However, sometimes I do think we rely too much on medical professionals and not enough on our own knowledge and ability to help ourselves.  The knowledge is open source these days.
Posts.Title: Embarassing, but I need relief!
